abstract.p: Photos of upturned collars, full skirts and black and white Chanel suits seen in New York City (On the Street column) (M)

block.p: Thousands of fashion fans, in Paris recently for the spring 2001 collections, wore their newest clothes, and three ideas stood out.

First was the gesture of wearing the suit jacket collar turned up, not to keep out the cold but as a do-it-yourself fashion statement. The idea, a signature of Hedi Slimane, top far left, who designs at Dior, became a preshow statement for Tom Ford, who dressed 60 models in newly proportioned Saint Laurent pantsuits, above left, as a kind of honor guard leading up to the Rodin Museum, bottom left, and out into the back garden for his show. There, Mr. Ford, who studied architecture, had designed a spectacular black rectangular structure set in the garden to seat his 800 guests, below.

The third and biggest force continued to be Chanel. Several hundred women wore their new black and white Chanels, bottom right.
